technical_features.feature_name: External Quantum Efficiency (EQE) of Red InP QLEDs
technical_features.source_sentence: The device showed an outstanding EQE of 21.4%, which is comparable to that of the best Cd-chalcogenide-based QLEDs.

technical_features.feature_name: Maximum Luminance of Red InP QLEDs
technical_features.source_sentence: InP/ZnSe/ZnS red QLEDs [...] showed [...] maximum luminance of 100,000 cd m⁻².
InP-based green QLEDs [...] showed [...] EQE of 13.6%.

technical_features.feature_name: Maximum Luminance of Green InP QLEDs
technical_features.source_sentence: InP-based green QLEDs [...] showed [...] maximum luminance of 13,900 cd m⁻².
ZnSeTe blue QLEDs [...] showed [...] EQE of 20.2%.

technical_features.feature_name: Maximum Luminance of ZnSeTe Blue QLEDs
technical_features.source_sentence: ZnSeTe blue QLEDs [...] showed [...] maximum luminance of 88,900 cd m⁻².
QLEDs could be fabricated as an ultrathin-type device whose entire thickness is <3 μm including encapsulation layers.
Samsung [...] demonstrated a 4″-scale flexible full-color QD display by combining 413 ppi RGB QLEDs.

technical_features.feature_name: Photoluminescence Quantum Yield (PLQY) of CdSe/ZnS QDs
technical_features.source_sentence: High-quality type I core/shell QDs [...] exhibit [...] PLQY, typically 70–100% for CdSe/ZnS QDs.
Core/shell QDs with gradually alloyed intermediate shell are preferred because of the low energy barrier for charge carrier injection.
ZnO nanoparticle (NP)-based electron transport layers (ETLs) and the organic hole transport layers (HTLs) are commonly employed.
